responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Arbitrary command injection in cleanup scripts
    analysis: |
      The cleanup scripts in build/sysroot/usr/share/casaos/cleanup/service.d/user-service read user input
      with `read -r input` and then use that input in a case statement without properly sanitizing it first. 
      This could allow an attacker to break out of the case statement and inject arbitrary commands.

      For example, if the attacker entered "; malicious command" at the prompt, the "; malicious command" 
      part would be executed as a separate command after the case statement, allowing arbitrary code execution.

      The scripts also call rm -rf on user-supplied paths, which could potentially be abused to delete
      unintended files or directories.
    cwe: CWE-78
    function_names:
      - onCtrlC
    filenames:
      - build/sysroot/usr/share/casaos/cleanup/service.d/user-service/ubuntu/cleanup-user-service.sh
      - build/sysroot/usr/share/casaos/cleanup/service.d/user-service/ubuntu/jammy/cleanup-user-service.sh
      - build/sysroot/usr/share/casaos/cleanup/service.d/user-service/arch/cleanup-user-service.sh
      - build/sysroot/usr/share/casaos/cleanup/service.d/user-service/debian/cleanup-user-service.sh
      - build/sysroot/usr/share/casaos/cleanup/service.d/user-service/debian/bullseye/cleanup-user-service.sh
    classification: very promising
  - headline: Potential path traversal via CASA_DB_PATH
    analysis: |
      The cleanup scripts set CASA_DB_PATH by extracting it from the configuration file using grep. 
      The extracted value is then used to construct file paths for deletion with rm.

      However, there is no validation on the value of CASA_DB_PATH. If an attacker could control
      the contents of the configuration file, they may be able to include relative paths containing
      "../" to traverse outside the intended directory and have rm delete unintended files.
    cwe: CWE-22
    function_names:
      - Show
    filenames:
      - build/sysroot/usr/share/casaos/cleanup/service.d/user-service/ubuntu/cleanup-user-service.sh
      - build/sysroot/usr/share/casaos/cleanup/service.d/user-service/ubuntu/jammy/cleanup-user-service.sh
      - build/sysroot/usr/share/casaos/cleanup/service.d/user-service/arch/cleanup-user-service.sh 
      - build/sysroot/usr/share/casaos/cleanup/service.d/user-service/debian/cleanup-user-service.sh
      - build/sysroot/usr/share/casaos/cleanup/service.d/user-service/debian/bullseye/cleanup-user-service.sh
    classification: slightly promising
  - headline: Using curl to download migration tools over HTTP
    analysis: |  
      The migration script build/scripts/migration/script.d/02-migrate-user-service.sh uses curl to
      download migration tool archives over HTTP without TLS. The archives are extracted and the tools
      inside are executed.
      
      An attacker able to intercept this HTTP traffic, e.g. on an insecure network, could perform a 
      man-in-the-middle attack to send a malicious archive containing executables that would then run
      with the privileges of the user running this migration script.
    cwe: CWE-829
    function_names: 
      - __get_download_domain  
    filenames:
      - build/scripts/migration/script.d/02-migrate-user-service.sh
    classification: very promising
```

leads.headline: Arbitrary command injection in cleanup scripts
leads.analysis:
The cleanup scripts in build/sysroot/usr/share/casaos/cleanup/service.d/user-service read user input
with read -r input and then use that input in a case statement without properly sanitizing it first. 
This could allow an attacker to break out of the case statement and inject arbitrary commands.

For example, if the attacker entered "; malicious command" at the prompt, the "; malicious command" 
part would be executed as a separate command after the case statement, allowing arbitrary code execution.

The scripts also call rm -rf on user-supplied paths, which could potentially be abused to delete
unintended files or directories.

leads.headline: Potential path traversal via CASA_DB_PATH
leads.analysis:
The cleanup scripts set CASA_DB_PATH by extracting it from the configuration file using grep. 
The extracted value is then used to construct file paths for deletion with rm.

However, there is no validation on the value of CASA_DB_PATH. If an attacker could control
the contents of the configuration file, they may be able to include relative paths containing
"../" to traverse outside the intended directory and have rm delete unintended files.

leads.headline: Using curl to download migration tools over HTTP
leads.analysis:
The migration script build/scripts/migration/script.d/02-migrate-user-service.sh uses curl to
download migration tool archives over HTTP without TLS. The archives are extracted and the tools
inside are executed.

An attacker able to intercept this HTTP traffic, e.g. on an insecure network, could perform a 
man-in-the-middle attack to send a malicious archive containing executables that would then run
with the privileges of the user running this migration script.
